default_solve_params()[source]¶

Return type:dict
form_cost_ftn(u, u_ob, integral, kind='log', verbose=True)[source]¶

Forms and returns a cost functional for use with adjoint calculations such as optimize().

The choices for kind are :

  1. log – logarithmic cost
\[\mathscr{J}(u) = \frac{1}{2} \int_{\Gamma} \ln \left( \frac{ \Vert u \Vert_2 }{ \Vert u_{\mathrm{ob}} \Vert_2 + \epsilon } \right)^2 \mathrm{d}\Gamma\]
  1. l2 – \(L_2\)-norm cost
\[\mathscr{J}(u) = \frac{1}{2} \int_{\Gamma} \Vert u - u_{\mathrm{ob}} \Vert_2^2 \mathrm{d}\Gamma\]
  1. ratio – ratio cost
\[\mathscr{J}(u) = \frac{1}{2} \int_{\Gamma} \left( 1 - \left( \frac{ \Vert u \Vert_2 }{ \Vert u_{\mathrm{ob}} \Vert_2 + \epsilon } \right) \right)^2 \mathrm{d}\Gamma\]
  1. l1 – absolute value \(L_1\) norm cost
\[\mathscr{J}(u) = \int_{\Gamma} \left| u - u_{\mathrm{ob}} \right| \mathrm{d}\Gamma\]

The parameter \(\epsilon\) is on the order of machine precision.

Parameters:
  • u (dolfin_adjoint.Function) – the state variable
  • u_ob (dolfin.Function) – observation of the state variable u
  • integral (Boundary) – measure over which to integrate (see calculate_boundaries())
  • kind (string) – kind of cost function to use
  • verbose (boolean) – inform what the function is doing.
form_reg_ftn(c, integral, kind='TV', verbose=True)[source]¶

Formulates a regularization functional for use with optimization of the control parameter \(c\) given by c over the integral integral.

The choices for kind are :

  1. tikhonov – Tikhonov regularization
\[\mathscr{R}(c) = \frac{1}{2} \int_{\Gamma} \nabla c \cdot \nabla c\ \mathrm{d}\Gamma\]
  1. tv – total variation regularization
\[\mathscr{R}(c) = \int_{\Gamma} \left( \nabla c \cdot \nabla c + c_0 \right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\ \mathrm{d}\Gamma,\]
  1. square – squared regularization
\[\mathscr{R}(c) = \frac{1}{2} \int_{\Gamma} c^2\ \mathrm{d}\Gamma,\]
  1. abs – absolute regularization
\[\mathscr{R}(c) = \int_{\Gamma} |c|\ \mathrm{d}\Gamma,\]
Parameters:
  • c (dolfin.Function) – the control variable
  • integral (Boundary) – measure over which to integrate (see calculate_boundaries())
  • kind (string) – kind of regularization to use
optimize(u, u_ob, I, control, J_measure, R_measure, bounds, method='ipopt', max_iter=100, adj_save_vars=None, adj_callback=None, post_adj_callback=None)[source]¶

Momentum balance¶

class momentum.Momentum(model, solve_params=None, linear=False, use_lat_bcs=False, use_pressure_bc=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Abstract class outlines the structure of a momentum calculation.

Lagrangian()[source]¶

Returns the Lagrangian of the momentum equations.

calc_q_fric()[source]¶

Solve for the friction heat term stored in model.q_fric.

color()[source]¶

return the default color for this class.

dLdc(L, c)[source]¶

Returns the derivative of the Lagrangian consisting of adjoint-computed self.Lam values w.r.t. the control variable c, i.e.,

\[\frac{\mathrm{d} L}{\mathrm{d} c} = \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} c} \mathscr{L} \left( \lambda \right),\]

where \(\mathscr{L}\) is the Lagrangian computed by Lagrangian() and \(\lambda\) is the adjoint variable.

default_solve_params()[source]¶

Returns a set of default solver parameters that yield good performance

get_Lam()[source]¶

Return the adjoint function for self.U.

get_Phi()[source]¶

Return the test function for self.U, self.Phi.

get_U()[source]¶

Return the velocity Function self.U.

get_dU()[source]¶

Return the trial function for self.U, self.dU.

get_residual()[source]¶

Returns the momentum residual self.mom_F.

initialize(model, solve_params=None, linear=False, use_lat_bcs=False, use_pressure_bc=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Here we set up the problem, and do all of the differentiation and memory allocation type stuff. Note that any Momentum object must call this method. See the existing child Momentum objects for reference.

linearize the viscosity using the velocity stored in model.U3.

reset the momentum to the original configuration.

Solves for the adjoint variables self.Lam from the Hamiltonian <H>.

solve_pressure(annotate=False)[source]¶

viscosity(U)[source]¶

calculates and returns the viscosity \(\eta\) using velocity vector U with components u, v, w.
